title: Error message when using inner static with type parameters is misleading

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
This code

```rust
fn x<T: Default>() {
    static a: T = T::default();
}
```

generates this error:

```text
error[E0401]: can't use type parameters from outer function; try using a local type parameter instead
 --> src/main.rs:2:15
  |
2 |     static a: T = T::default();
  |               ^ use of type variable from outer function

error[E0401]: can't use type parameters from outer function; try using a local type parameter instead
 --> src/main.rs:2:19
  |
2 |     static a: T = T::default();
  |                   ^^^^^^^^^^ use of type variable from outer function

error: aborting due to 2 previous errors
```

which is misleading because a local type parameter is being used.

The [original](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/commit/0db50056aec603eadff2e7f2e8e6519824add552#diff-bcbfd0820dc70f27905e7d5f414b813e) message was different.

I have one question: why this is forbidden? There is an [issue](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/9186) with some discussion but I do not see why this is not possible.

Using static with type parameters is very useful, for example, defining thread local buffer for store temporary results (like in a sorting algorithm).
